content: If there are no objections, I'd like to add cover art to this puzzle.

I liked:
* the potential loss of commutativity wrt the binomial law
* the asymmetry wrt Pascal's triangle

I disliked:
* the lack of constraints to provide an order of magnitude of what to optimize for.
* my end code is a direct implementation of the statement (including combinatorial explosion, adding O(N) list access in for good measure), yet it passes.

As a result, I'm a bit confused by your comment saying you have to understand the sequence. I don't have the feeling that was my case!

I'd suggest special-casing the definition for endpoints, because the current wording says 0 (instead of "neutral element"), which makes sense as it's a description of Pascal's triangle, but makes implementation of the puzzle an exception-in-an-exception. OTOH, stopping in the corners instead of assuming half-unbounded sequences of neutrals could be argued to be part of the point of the problem. Not sure what's best here.

Anyway, good to go. (you can always edit or post a sequel if you want to follow up on my points :D )

(if you edit, make it to provide meaningful test names ;) )
Don't be fooled into thinking this is a very easy puzzle. The last few tests and validators are a bit tricky! You need to understand the sequence to solve it.
